We're also tracking a less addictive substance that's hazardous to your health.
Trans fats are being phased-out across this country.
Nine years after New York City banned them, the food industry has changed many recipes.
NPR's Allison Aubrey reports on the rise and fall of a uniquely harmful substance.
When trans fats entered the food supply back in the early 1900s, no one knew about their harmful effects.
In fact, industrial trans fats were considered a real technological innovation.
As Dariush Mozaffarian, the dean of the Tufts University Nutrition School, explains it, scientists had figured out how to turn liquid fats into solids.
Its original purpose was to take really inexpensive, plentiful vegetable oils and make them into a solid fat that could be used for baking and other processes.
Think Crisco Shortening and margarine.
But decades later, after trans fats had become ubiquitous in the food supply, it became clear that they were bad for us - really bad.
They raise the bad cholesterol, they lower the good cholesterol, but also raise inflammation, worsen the health of blood vessels.
There's really not any other dietary fat that has this constellation of harmful effects.
The Food and Drug Administration took its first action back in 2006.
They required manufacturers to label trans fats on all food packages.
And as consumers started looking for packages labeled as trans fat-free, the industry began to reformulate.
They turned to alternatives such as palm oil, which Mozaffarian says has been an improvement.
Any natural replacement is superior to partially hydrogenated vegetable oil, whether it's butter or palm oil or blends of oils.
The Grocery Manufacturers Association, a trade association, says over the last decade the industry has reduced its use of trans fats by about 85 percent.
Even Crisco is now made without any partially hydrogenated oils.
But there are exceptions - some ready-to-eat baked goods, pie crusts and microwave popcorn still contain a fair amount.
So in order to get most of the remaining 15 percent of trans fats out of the food supply, the FDA plans to step in again.
Any day now, the agency is expected to announce a final rule that could amount to a near ban of trans fats.
They may say trans fats no longer have so-called GRAS status - that's an acronym for generally recognized as safe.
Consumer advocate Michael Jacobson of the Center for Science in the Public Interest says this is a good move.
